content.webTitle: Malcolm Turnbull blasts 'cult' of executive pay and 'hypocrite' Shorten

fields.headline: Malcolm Turnbull blasts 'cult' of executive pay and 'hypocrite' Shorten
fields.bodyText: Malcolm Turnbull has taken aim at the “cult” of excessive executive pay and stepped up his attack on Bill Shorten, labelling him a hypocrite for pretending to be a “horny handed son of toil”. The prime minister made the comments in an interview on 3AW Radio on Friday in which he rejected the Coaliton senator Ian Macdonald’s call to retain politicians’ life gold travel pass and advocated that the government should take an ownership stake in infrastructure projects. Asked about the $5.6m pay packet of Australia Post’s chief executive, Ahmed Fahour, Turnbull said it was “way too much”, repeating a criticism he made earlier in the week. Turnbull said he had confidence in the Australia Post board and suggested that Fahour volunteer for a pay cut. He said the board independently set executives’ pay and Fahour’s contract dated back to the Labor government. “Ahmed Fahour is a very talented man … I have a high regard for him. But that is too much money for that job. “I think there are a lot of corporate CEOs, by the way, that are overpaid. I think there’s become a sort of, it’s almost a cult of excessive executive CEO remuneration.” The treasurer, Scott Morrison, agreed that Australians were confused by the scale of executive pay and said company boards making decisions about pay needed to be accountable to their shareholders and customers. “I think Australians when they look at these issues scratched their heads,” Morrison said. “That puts a greater accountability on boards, CEOs and executives to explain. “This trust between businesses and their customers and the community more generally is for them to manage and, like any other Australian, you see these things and sometimes you scratch your head.” Asked about Macdonald’s call on Thursday for the politicians’ travel pass to be retained, after Turnbull announced it would be abolished, the prime minister replied that politicians worked hard but if they thought they weren’t adequately paid they could resign or not recontest the election. “The gold pass is a relic of a bygone era of perks … It’s not the modern era, that’s why I’m abolishing them,” he said. “I know that some people feel aggrieved about it, but the idea that just because someone has been in parliament for 20 years, for the rest of their life can fly around at public expense, it’s almost Dickensian.” Turnbull said he was “not a hater” and did “not develop personal animosities towards people” but, explaining his attacks on Shorten this week, added it was “important to show him up for the hypocrite he is”. He said the Labor leader was “duplicitous” for changing his position on company tax and hypocritical for dining with billionaires while pretending to be “the horny handed son of toil”. Shorten held himself out as “a working-class hero, the champion of the common man”, he said, despite the Australian Workers’ Union trading away members’ penalty rates at Cleanevent and Chiquita Mushrooms during his time as its leader. “If you are representing someone, if you’re a union or lawyer … your job is to get the best deal for them and you’re certainly not entitled to be taking benefits yourself, and that’s exactly what the AWU did,” he said, citing findings of the trade union royal commission. Turnbull claimed his speech in question time was “ex tempore, off the cuff” after Shorten launched an attack based on the politics of envy against him. The prime minister said governments “should be more entrepreneurial”. “We’ve got to be prepared to invest in infrastructure … take an ownership stake in it, government’s can live on what by commercial standards is a very low rate of return.” Asked on FIVEaa in an earlier interview about state governments nationalising their electricity grids, Turnbull queried whether that would result in South Australia being cut off from the Victorian interconnector. “South Australia would become blacked out more often than not at that rate,” he said. Asked on 3AW about reports that the foreign minister, Julie Bishop, has said she is not concerned the US will tear up its free trade agreement, Turnbull said “nobody imagines any threat” to the deal because the US has a trade surplus with Australia. “Given that Donald Trump is worried about countries where it is the reverse, like with China, I don’t think we need be concerned about US Australia free trade agreement.” Turnbull said he did not admire Vladimir Putin, noting that Russia had invaded the Crimea peninsula in Ukraine and forces backed by its government had shot down the MH17 flight that killed Australians in “an act of terrorism”.
